THE NEWS== LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 4.

HOPKINS WINS EASILY
Virginians Outclassed by Strong Black
and Blue Eleven—Medical Students
Prominently in the Game.

Hopkins' rooters were given a
Pleasant treat last Saturday afternoon when the Black and Blue
Varsity Eleven defeated RandolphMacon, 26 to 0. Hopkins seems
to have struck its gait at last.
Marked improvement was noticed
in every branch of the game. The
tackling was good and the line was
much stronger. The plays were
run off in a snappy manner and
there was a much larger variety of
them. The week's secret practice
certainly wrought wonders with the
squad. The medical students who
have recently joined the team
showed up extremely well.
The game began with Bridgman
kicking off to Randolph-Macon.
The visitors ran the ball back to
the midfield, were held for downs,
and forced to punt. Captain Stollenwerck caught the pigskin and
made a splendid sprint of 80 yards
for a touchdown. Fulton kicked
the goal. The Virginians carried
the ball to Hopkins' 20-yard
line only to lose it. At all critical
moments the Hopkins line held
like a stone wall. In the second
quarter, by several successful end
runs and small gains through the
line, Hopkins carried the ball to
Randolph-Macon's 24-yard line.
Stollenwerck dropped back as if to
attempt a drop kick. Instead the
ball was passed to Bridgman, who
tore through the unsuspecting
Black and Yellow team, and was
not downed until he had crossed
the goal line. Fulton again kicked
goal.
Pieper scored the third touchdown shortly after the beginning
of the second half, and Fulton
missed goal. Stonie added three
more points to the credit of Hopkins by booting the spheroid over
the frowning crossbars from the
35-yar1 line.
After a punt had rolled over the
Virginian's goal line, Musser fell
on it and thus made the fourth
touchdown, as the field judge
Claimed the ball had been touched /
by a Randolph-Macon player.
Bridgman kicked goal. Hopkins
had the best of its opponents in
Punting and gained in almost
every exchange.
Porter, who was given a tryout
at quarterback, brought the spectators to their feet by several quarterback runs. He ran the team
very well and ably filled Stonie's
Place. McCabe played his usual
steady game at centre.
Hopkins, who played right end
for Randolph-Macon, is a Baltimore lad.

POLYTECHNIC DEFEATS SCRUBS
The Hopkins scrubs went down
to defeat at the hands of the first
team of the Polytechnic Institute
last Friday afternoon at Homewood
by the score of 9 to 0. The Boilermakers outplayed their opponents
from the start. Better teamwork
by the prep school players was a
big factor in the defeat of Hopkins.
The Polytechnic eleven has practiced together all season while the
scrubs did not know how they would
play until the game began.
Captain 'Platt, of the Poly team,
was the star of the game. He
made many substantial gains by
line plunging. The Polytechnic
team played straight football at all
times, and did not use a fake play
once during the game. A touchdown was made by Platt in the first
quarter after the Poly backs had
taken turns in rushing the ball
down the field. He also kicked
goal. The Poly team again advanced the ball in Hopkins territory
in the second half, and Captain
Platt dropped the pigskin over the
cross bars from the 20 yard line.
Hopkins was within an ace of
scoring a touchdown at two different times during the game. The
winners held the scrubs for downs,
the first time on their 2 yard line.
Porter and Rutherford. threw a
scare into the Polytechnic eleven
just before the end of the game

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 24, 1910.

In another column are printed
two letters that explain themselves
and deserve the thoughtful attention of all who are interested in
getting at the worth-while part of
a college training.
The annual
discussion of the usefulness or lack
of usefulness of the colleges as a
means of preparing the young men
of the land for their practical work
in life has been provoked as usual by
the commencing of another school
year. The advocates of utilitarian
training are making their accustomed attack on the educators of
the old school, who believe that
education is worth while whether
• it increases the immediate dollargetting capacity of the graduate or
not. Under these circumstances, we
consider it fortunate to be able to
publish the opinion of a practical
man who has been through the mill
himself and in after-life has found
at least one valuable feature of his
college training in a little-discussed
side of the undergraduate activities.
By all who are interested in
THE NEWS-LETTER, these letters
will be eagerly read, but they ought
to do more than recall the early
history of the paper. It is our
earnest hope that Mr. Thomson's
expectation may not be disappointed, and that his appreciation of the
value of such work may bring about
a revival of interest in the conduct of the college publications.

Again the pride of Hopkins is
humbled. This time the insignificance of the University as distinguished from the Hospital has
been pointed out by a taxicab
driver, who declared that the Hospital was the University, and if
there was any other Johns Hopkins
he didn't know where it was. We
accept the situation with resignation and hope fondly for the day
when no citizen of Baltimore will
have to consult the City Directory
before telling a stranger the way to
reach McCoy FIall.

ampitheatre to hear a lecture by
Dr. Louis Wickham, of Paris, on
the subject "Treatment of Tumors
by the Action of Radium." The
results of the work upon which Dr.
\Vickham spoke are so striking that
one of the well-known physicians
present declared he considered it
equal in value to the discovery of
antiseptic surgery itself.
It is to be regretted that in the
somewhat overdrawn newspaper accounts of the recent brilliant experiments at the Rockefeller Institute, due credit was not given to
Dr. M. T. Burrows (M.D., Johns
Hopkins, '09). Dr. Burrows was
joint author with Dr. Alexius Carrel of the article, "Cultivation of
Mammalian Cells Outside the
Body," in the current journal of
the American Medical Association,
and it is expressly stated therein
that he had an important share in
this work.

At a business meeting of the
Scientific Association of the University, held in Hopkins Hall, on
last Wednesday afternoon, the following officers were elected:
President—Prof. Harry C. Jones.
Vice-President—Prof. J. B. Watson.
Secretary—Dr. John A. Anderson.
A series of two meetings per
month during the session was determined upon, one to be of a semipublic nature, in Hopkins Hall, the
other at the Hopkins Club, at which
the work being done in the graduate departments will be discussed.
ALUMNI NOTES
James B. Kennedy, Ph.D., '07,
who was formerly professor of
political economy at Wells College,
now holds the 'same position in
Union College, Schenectady, N. Y.
Theodore W. Glocker, Ph.D.,
'07, is acting as director of the research work in the Boston School
for Social Workers, an institution
maintained by Harvard University
and Simmons College.
Ernest R. Spedden, Ph.D., '09,
has resigned his position as instructor in political economy at Purdue
University, and is now engaged in
the study of law in this city.

ganization as was Mr. Hill. It is

Crothers and Mr. Straus, having

be Governor and the other United
States Senator. The selection of

to his support the anti-organization
Republicans in the State, but
whether subsequent events will
show this remains to be seen.

Tuesday, October ii, witnessed
the opening of the college courses
for teachers which are offered
jointly by the University and
Goucher College. This is the
second year for these courses to
be given, and by the increased enrollment, growing interest is manifested. Last year's membership of
sixty-nine was exceeded by the
registration of eighty-three some
time ago, and many additional applicants have since been accepted.
The courses in most cases correspond closely to those given in
the first and second years of the
regular undergraduate work. They
will be conducted by a faculty composed of four members of the staff
of Goucher College, and nine of
that of the University. The courses
offered and the instructors in each
are as follows:
English Literature-Chaucer, Spenser, and the
History of English Literature from the seventh to the seventeenth century.
Professor Greene.
English Composition-Rhetoric and Composition
Dr. French.
German-1. Modern Prose
Professor Wood and Dr. Roulston
2. Advanced Grammar- The Modern
Drama
Professor Wood
French-1. Elementary French Professor Brush
2. Advanced French (corresponding to
French 2)
Professor Brush
Lalin-Livy,Terence, Catullus-Private Reading
-Prose Composition
Professor Mustard
Chemistry-Based on Remsen's Briefer CourseLaboratory. Professor Renouf and Dr. Gilpin
Education-The History of Education
Professor Buchner
Biology-Class-work and Laboratory
Professor Kellicott
History-t. English History
Professor Abel
2. Mtditeval History..
Professor Abel
Mathematics-i. Algebra and Analytic Geometry
Professor Maltbie
2. Calculus
Professor Bacon

Instruction will be given as far
as possible in the buildings of the
University,though some few classes
and laboratory exercises may be
held at Goucher College.
The courses are open to all who
have satisfied the matriculation requirements of the Hopkins or of
Goucher College. Admission is in
the hands of the committee in
cnarge of college courses for
teachers, consisting of Professors
Edward P. Buchner and Harry L.
Wilson of the University, and
Dean John B. Van Meter of
Goucher College.
Not all of those who were present
at the opening of classes on Tuesday
are freshmen, so to speak. Many
who attended courses last year have
returned to continue their work,
some at least with the hope of securing the baccalaureate degree, which
will be granted upon the attainment
of credits to the amount of sixty
units, or hours. As the courses
are open to both men and women,
an agreement has been reached between the University and Goucher

1910

College, whereby the degree is to
be conterred upon the women by
the latter, upon the men by the
tormer.
Whether these teachers' courses
shall form a permanent feature in
the work of the University is as
yet uncertain. At priesent, ,they
are little more than an interesting
experiment. It is to be hoped that
the experiment will succeed. It
seems to present a great opportunity for benefit, both to Baltimore
and to the University.
Some time ago, it will be recollected, the local newspapers were
tilled with reports that many school
'teachers were breaking down under
the severe requirements which are
now imposed upon them. Many of
these teachers, in an effort to satisfy the new derriands, spend their
vacation at summer schools and devote to study the time necessary
for recreation. As a result, it was
said, their health is impaired. It
should seem that a remedy for this
difficulty might be found in these
teachers' courses. They afford an
opportunity to get right here in
Baltimore, in a spare hour or two
every day, courses of instruction
equal to those given in the freshman and sophomore years of the
best colleges in the country.
The teachers' courses also appear to promise material advantage
to the Hopkins. By their means,
the University is brought into direct contact with men and women
in whose charge rests the education
of by far the largest part of the
youth of the community. The educators of the people become Hopkins men and women. And hereby
it might be brought to pass that the
people should come to look upon
their local University with greater
feelings of veneration and affection
than they have hitherto done.
Hopkins-St. Johns, November 12.

At last a date has been fixed, subject to ratification by the Athletic
Board, for the Hopkins-St. Johns
football game. Manager Williams
Haynes, of the Hopkins team, and
E. A. Harrison, of St. Johns, made
a special trip to Lancaster, Pa.,
last week to induce Franklin and
Marshall College to cancel their
game with St. Johns for November
12, in order that the latter's team
might come to Homewood on that
date.
After a conference with Dr. Beck,
of the faculty advisory committee
on athletics, they effected the above
arrangement, and also induced
Franklin and Marshall to take on
Gallaudet for the 12th, and thus
leave Hopkins free for the St. Johns
game. The abandoned St. JohnsFranklin. and Marshall game will
be' played next year, and a baseball
game was incidentally arranged for
the Hopkins team with one from
the Lancaster institution.
Manager Haynes is also negotiating with Rutgers for a football
game here on Thanksgiving, which
should prove a drawing card if the
arrangements can be made.

Wood Lectures in London.

Prof. Robert W. Wood, of this
University, delivered the Thomas
Young oration before the Optical
Society, in London, on September
29. He described some of the apparatus with which he has been experimenting lately. The first was
what he calls an echelette grating.
It is a grating ruled with a crystal
of carborundum on gold deposited
on copper. It has been used to determine the causes which throw the
greater part of the light of a definite wave-length into one particular
spectrum.
Dr. Wood described also his new
mercury telescope and the method
by which he took pictures by infrared and ultra-violet rays.

THE NEWS== LETTER
VOL. XV, NO. 4.

HOPKINS WINS EASILY
Virginians Outclassed by Strong Black
and Blue Eleven—Medical Students
Prominently in the Game.

Hopkins' rooters were given a
Pleasant treat last Saturday afternoon when the Black and Blue
Varsity Eleven defeated RandolphMacon, 26 to 0. Hopkins seems
to have struck its gait at last.
Marked improvement was noticed
in every branch of the game. The
tackling was good and the line was
much stronger. The plays were
run off in a snappy manner and
there was a much larger variety of
them. The week's secret practice
certainly wrought wonders with the
squad. The medical students who
have recently joined the team
showed up extremely well.
The game began with Bridgman
kicking off to Randolph-Macon.
The visitors ran the ball back to
the midfield, were held for downs,
and forced to punt. Captain Stollenwerck caught the pigskin and
made a splendid sprint of 80 yards
for a touchdown. Fulton kicked
the goal. The Virginians carried
the ball to Hopkins' 20-yard
line only to lose it. At all critical
moments the Hopkins line held
like a stone wall. In the second
quarter, by several successful end
runs and small gains through the
line, Hopkins carried the ball to
Randolph-Macon's 24-yard line.
Stollenwerck dropped back as if to
attempt a drop kick. Instead the
ball was passed to Bridgman, who
tore through the unsuspecting
Black and Yellow team, and was
not downed until he had crossed
the goal line. Fulton again kicked
goal.
Pieper scored the third touchdown shortly after the beginning
of the second half, and Fulton
missed goal. Stonie added three
more points to the credit of Hopkins by booting the spheroid over
the frowning crossbars from the
35-yar1 line.
After a punt had rolled over the
Virginian's goal line, Musser fell
on it and thus made the fourth
touchdown, as the field judge
Claimed the ball had been touched /
by a Randolph-Macon player.
Bridgman kicked goal. Hopkins
had the best of its opponents in
Punting and gained in almost
every exchange.
Porter, who was given a tryout
at quarterback, brought the spectators to their feet by several quarterback runs. He ran the team
very well and ably filled Stonie's
Place. McCabe played his usual
steady game at centre.
Hopkins, who played right end
for Randolph-Macon, is a Baltimore lad.

POLYTECHNIC DEFEATS SCRUBS
The Hopkins scrubs went down
to defeat at the hands of the first
team of the Polytechnic Institute
last Friday afternoon at Homewood
by the score of 9 to 0. The Boilermakers outplayed their opponents
from the start. Better teamwork
by the prep school players was a
big factor in the defeat of Hopkins.
The Polytechnic eleven has practiced together all season while the
scrubs did not know how they would
play until the game began.
Captain 'Platt, of the Poly team,
was the star of the game. He
made many substantial gains by
line plunging. The Polytechnic
team played straight football at all
times, and did not use a fake play
once during the game. A touchdown was made by Platt in the first
quarter after the Poly backs had
taken turns in rushing the ball
down the field. He also kicked
goal. The Poly team again advanced the ball in Hopkins territory
in the second half, and Captain
Platt dropped the pigskin over the
cross bars from the 20 yard line.
Hopkins was within an ace of

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 24, 1910.

In another column are printed
two letters that explain themselves
and deserve the thoughtful attention of all who are interested in
getting at the worth-while part of
a college training.
The annual
discussion of the usefulness or lack
of usefulness of the colleges as a
means of preparing the young men
of the land for their practical work
in life has been provoked as usual by
the commencing of another school
year. The advocates of utilitarian
training are making their accustomed attack on the educators of
the old school, who believe that
education is worth while whether
• it increases the immediate dollargetting capacity of the graduate or
not. Under these circumstances, we
consider it fortunate to be able to
publish the opinion of a practical
man who has been through the mill
himself and in after-life has found
at least one valuable feature of his
college training in a little-discussed
side of the undergraduate activities.
By all who are interested in
THE NEWS-LETTER, these letters
will be eagerly read, but they ought
to do more than recall the early
history of the paper. It is our
earnest hope that Mr. Thomson's
expectation may not be disappointed, and that his appreciation of the
value of such work may bring about
a revival of interest in the conduct of the college publications.

Again the pride of Hopkins is
humbled. This time the insignificance of the University as distinguished from the Hospital has
been pointed out by a taxicab
driver, who declared that the Hospital was the University, and if
there was any other Johns Hopkins
he didn't know where it was. We
accept the situation with resignation and hope fondly for the day
when no citizen of Baltimore will
have to consult the City Directory
before telling a stranger the way to
reach McCoy FIall.

Tuesday, October ii, witnessed
the opening of the college courses
for teachers which are offered
jointly by the University and
Goucher College. This is the
second year for these courses to
be given, and by the increased enrollment, growing interest is manifested. Last year's membership of
sixty-nine was exceeded by the
registration of eighty-three some
time ago, and many additional applicants have since been accepted.
The courses in most cases correspond closely to those given in
the first and second years of the
regular undergraduate work. They
will be conducted by a faculty composed of four members of the staff
of Goucher College, and nine of
that of the University. The courses
offered and the instructors in each
are as follows:
English Literature-Chaucer, Spenser, and the
History of English Literature from the seventh to the seventeenth century.
Professor Greene.
English Composition-Rhetoric and Composition
Dr. French.
German-1. Modern Prose
Professor Wood and Dr. Roulston
2. Advanced Grammar- The Modern
Drama
Professor Wood
French-1. Elementary French Professor Brush
2. Advanced French (corresponding to
French 2)
Professor Brush
Lalin-Livy,Terence, Catullus-Private Reading
-Prose Composition
Professor Mustard
Chemistry-Based on Remsen's Briefer CourseLaboratory. Professor Renouf and Dr. Gilpin
Education-The History of Education
Professor Buchner
Biology-Class-work and Laboratory
Professor Kellicott
History-t. English History
Professor Abel
2. Mtditeval History..
Professor Abel
Mathematics-i. Algebra and Analytic Geometry
Professor Maltbie
2. Calculus
Professor Bacon

Instruction will be given as far
as possible in the buildings of the
University,though some few classes
and laboratory exercises may be
held at Goucher College.
The courses are open to all who
have satisfied the matriculation requirements of the Hopkins or of
Goucher College. Admission is in
the hands of the committee in
cnarge of college courses for
teachers, consisting of Professors
Edward P. Buchner and Harry L.
Wilson of the University, and
Dean John B. Van Meter of
Goucher College.
Not all of those who were present
at the opening of classes on Tuesday
are freshmen, so to speak. Many
who attended courses last year have
returned to continue their work,
some at least with the hope of securing the baccalaureate degree, which
will be granted upon the attainment
of credits to the amount of sixty
units, or hours. As the courses
are open to both men and women,
an agreement has been reached between the University and Goucher

1910

College, whereby the degree is to
be conterred upon the women by
the latter, upon the men by the
tormer.
Whether these teachers' courses
shall form a permanent feature in
the work of the University is as
yet uncertain. At priesent, ,they
are little more than an interesting
experiment. It is to be hoped that
the experiment will succeed. It
seems to present a great opportunity for benefit, both to Baltimore
and to the University.
Some time ago, it will be recollected, the local newspapers were
tilled with reports that many school
'teachers were breaking down under
the severe requirements which are
now imposed upon them. Many of
these teachers, in an effort to satisfy the new derriands, spend their
vacation at summer schools and devote to study the time necessary
for recreation. As a result, it was
said, their health is impaired. It
should seem that a remedy for this
difficulty might be found in these
teachers' courses. They afford an
opportunity to get right here in
Baltimore, in a spare hour or two
every day, courses of instruction
equal to those given in the freshman and sophomore years of the
best colleges in the country.
The teachers' courses also appear to promise material advantage
to the Hopkins. By their means,
the University is brought into direct contact with men and women
in whose charge rests the education
of by far the largest part of the
youth of the community. The educators of the people become Hopkins men and women. And hereby
it might be brought to pass that the
people should come to look upon
their local University with greater
feelings of veneration and affection
than they have hitherto done.
Hopkins-St. Johns, November 12.

At last a date has been fixed, subject to ratification by the Athletic
Board, for the Hopkins-St. Johns
football game. Manager Williams
Haynes, of the Hopkins team, and
E. A. Harrison, of St. Johns, made
a special trip to Lancaster, Pa.,
last week to induce Franklin and
Marshall College to cancel their
game with St. Johns for November
12, in order that the latter's team
might come to Homewood on that
date.
After a conference with Dr. Beck,
of the faculty advisory committee
on athletics, they effected the above
arrangement, and also induced
Franklin and Marshall to take on
Gallaudet for the 12th, and thus
leave Hopkins free for the St. Johns
game. The abandoned St. JohnsFranklin. and Marshall game will
be' played next year, and a baseball
game was incidentally arranged for
the Hopkins team with one from
the Lancaster institution.
Manager Haynes is also negotiating with Rutgers for a football
game here on Thanksgiving, which
should prove a drawing card if the
arrangements can be made.

Wood Lectures in London.

Prof. Robert W. Wood, of this
University, delivered the Thomas
Young oration before the Optical
Society, in London, on September
29. He described some of the apparatus with which he has been experimenting lately. The first was
what he calls an echelette grating.
It is a grating ruled with a crystal
of carborundum on gold deposited
on copper. It has been used to determine the causes which throw the
greater part of the light of a definite wave-length into one particular
spectrum.
Dr. Wood described also his new
mercury telescope and the method
by which he took pictures by infrared and ultra-violet rays.
